items.standfirst: The announcement marks a critical response to persistent staffing shortages caused by the prolonged government shutdown.
items.content: The announcement marks a critical response to persistent staffing shortages caused by the prolonged government shutdown.

items.title: Transportation secretary announces 10% reduction in U.S. air traffic
items.standfirst: The FAA will reduce U.S. air traffic by 10% at 40 U.S. locations starting on Friday due to the government shutdown.
items.content: The FAA will reduce U.S. air traffic by 10% at 40 U.S. locations starting on Friday due to the government shutdown.

items.title: US to cut flights 10% at 40 airports because of government shutdown
items.standfirst: Transportation secretary Sean Duffy says reductions will start Friday to keep air travel safe
items.content: Transportation secretary Sean Duffy says reductions will start Friday to keep air travel safe

items.title: US to cut airline traffic by 10% due to shutdown, Trump transport chief says
items.standfirst: Sean Duffy says cuts at 40 locations to reduce stress on air traffic controllers will start Friday if solution not foundThe transportation secretary, Sean Duffy, and the FAA administrator, Bryan Bedford, said on Wednesday the federal government would be reducing airline traffic by 10% at 40 “high volume markets” beginning on Friday if the government shutdown does not end by then.The announcement did not specify which 40 airports would see the reduction and said that a complete list would be announced on Thursday with cuts likely at the nation’s 30 busiest airports, including those serving New York, Washington DC, Chicago, Atlanta, Los Angeles and Dallas. The reduction will affect cargo, private and passenger traffic. Continue reading...
items.content: Sean Duffy says cuts at 40 locations to reduce stress on air traffic controllers will start Friday if solution not foundThe transportation secretary, Sean Duffy, and the FAA administrator, Bryan Bedford, said on Wednesday the federal government would be reducing airline traffic by 10% at 40 “high volume markets” beginning on Friday if the government shutdown does not end by then.The announcement did not specify which 40 airports would see the reduction and said that a complete list would be announced on Thursday with cuts likely at the nation’s 30 busiest airports, including those serving New York, Washington DC, Chicago, Atlanta, Los Angeles and Dallas. The reduction will affect cargo, private and passenger traffic. Continue reading...

items.title: US to cut flights at 40 airports if shutdown doesn't end, transportation secretary warns
items.standfirst: Flight capacity will be cut 10% across the country, as air traffic controllers report experiencing fatigue, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said.
items.content: Flight capacity will be cut 10% across the country, as air traffic controllers report experiencing fatigue, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said.

items.title: FAA cancels thousands of flights amid US government shutdown strain
items.standfirst: The Federal Aviation Administration will reduce air traffic by 10% across 40 major markets from Friday to maintain safety, as unpaid air traffic controllers face growing fatigue and staff shortages during the longest government shutdown on record.
items.content: The Federal Aviation Administration will reduce air traffic by 10% across 40 major markets from Friday to maintain safety, as unpaid air traffic controllers face growing fatigue and staff shortages during the longest government shutdown on record.

items.title: FAA Plan to Cut Flights Might Not Be an Utter Nightmare
items.standfirst: The US government is aiming to ease the pressure on air traffic controllers suffering shutdown-related woes by curtailing flights. But airlines have experience with this kind of sudden disruption.
items.content: The US government is aiming to ease the pressure on air traffic controllers suffering shutdown-related woes by curtailing flights. But airlines have experience with this kind of sudden disruption.

items.title: FAA will reduce air traffic by 10% at many airports to maintain safety
items.standfirst: The Federal Aviation Administration will reduce air traffic at many busy airports to maintain safety during the government shutdown, which has led to staffing shortages of air traffic controllers.
items.content: The Federal Aviation Administration will reduce air traffic at many busy airports to maintain safety during the government shutdown, which has led to staffing shortages of air traffic controllers.(Image credit: Tasos Katopodis)

items.title: FAA to reduce flights by 10 percent as US government shutdown drags on
items.standfirst: The agency made the announcement as it confronts staffing shortages caused by air traffic controllers.
items.content: The agency made the announcement as it confronts staffing shortages caused by air traffic controllers.

items.title: U.S. reducing airline traffic at 40 locations due to shutdown, Secretary Duffy says
items.standfirst: The U.S. will reduce flight capacity by 10% at 40 airports starting Friday due to the government shutdown, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy announced on Wednesday. Capt. Laura Einsetler, an experienced commercial pilot, joins CBS News 24/7 with her reaction.
items.content: The U.S. will reduce flight capacity by 10% at 40 airports starting Friday due to the government shutdown, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy announced on Wednesday. Capt. Laura Einsetler, an experienced commercial pilot, joins CBS News 24/7 with her reaction.

ai_summary: The US will reduce air traffic by 10% at 40 locations starting Friday.
The reduction is due to staffing shortages caused by the government shutdown.
The cuts will affect cargo, private, and passenger traffic across the country.
The FAA and transportation secretary announced the planned reductions on Wednesday.
The specific airports affected will be announced on Thursday, likely including major hubs.

clusters.title: Philippines declares state of calamity as typhoon death toll rises to 114

items.title: Philippines declares state of calamity as typhoon death toll rises to 114
items.standfirst: Kalmaegi left the Philippines on Thursday morning and is currently moving toward central Vietnam.
items.content: Kalmaegi left the Philippines on Thursday morning and is currently moving toward central Vietnam.

items.title: After battering the Philippines, deadly Typhoon Kalmaegi moves toward Vietnam
items.standfirst: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. declared a state of emergency on Thursday after Typhoon Kalmaegi left at least 114 people dead and more than 100 missing in central provinces.
items.content: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. declared a state of emergency on Thursday after Typhoon Kalmaegi left at least 114 people dead and more than 100 missing in central provinces.(Image credit: Jacqueline Hernandez)

items.title: Typhoon Kalmaegi bears down on Vietnam after 114 killed in the Philippines

items.content: Meteorologists have warned that the typhoon has regained strength as it barrels towards Vietnam's central regions.

items.title: Philippines declares state of emergency after typhoon kills 114
items.standfirst: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. declared a state of emergency on Thursday after Typhoon Kalmaegi claimed at least 114 lives, the Associated Press reported.Another 127 people were still missi...
items.content: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. declared a state of emergency on Thursday after Typhoon Kalmaegi claimed at least 114 lives, the Associated Press reported.Another 127 people were still missi...

items.title: Philippines declares state of emergency after typhoon Kalmaegi death toll passes 100
items.standfirst: The deaths were mostly from drowning in flash floods, with 127 people still missing, many in the hard-hit central province of CebuPhilippine president Ferdinand Marcos Jr has declared a state of emergency after typhoon Kalmaegi left at least 114 people dead and nearly 130 missing in central provinces in the deadliest natural disaster to hit the country this year.The deaths were mostly from drowning in flash floods, and 127 people were still missing, many in the hard-hit central province of Cebu. The tropical cyclone blew out of the archipelago on Wednesday into the South China Sea. Continue reading...
items.content: The deaths were mostly from drowning in flash floods, with 127 people still missing, many in the hard-hit central province of CebuPhilippine president Ferdinand Marcos Jr has declared a state of emergency after typhoon Kalmaegi left at least 114 people dead and nearly 130 missing in central provinces in the deadliest natural disaster to hit the country this year.The deaths were mostly from drowning in flash floods, and 127 people were still missing, many in the hard-hit central province of Cebu. The tropical cyclone blew out of the archipelago on Wednesday into the South China Sea. Continue reading...

items.title: Philippine president declares state of emergency in the wake of Typhoon Kalmaegi
items.standfirst: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. declared a state of emergency on Thursday after Typhoon Kalmaegi left at least 114 people dead and hundreds missing in the country’s central provinces in what is the deadliest natural disaster to strike the Philippines this year.
items.content: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. declared a state of emergency on Thursday after Typhoon Kalmaegi left at least 114 people dead and hundreds missing in the country’s central provinces in what is the deadliest natural disaster to strike the Philippines this year.

items.title: Typhoon Kalmaegi death toll hits 114 in Philippines; storm rebuilds strength as it heads to Vietnam
Aerial images show destruction of Typhoon Kalmaegi in Philippines - with at least 66 killed
items.standfirst: At least 66 people have died after Typhoon Kalmaegi struck the Philippines, as footage emerges showing the scale of destruction.
items.content: At least 66 people have died after Typhoon Kalmaegi struck the Philippines, as footage emerges showing the scale of destruction.

ai_summary: Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 114 people in the Philippines.
Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. declared a state of emergency.
Over 100 people are still missing in the central provinces.
The deaths were primarily from drowning in flash floods.
The typhoon is moving toward Vietnam after leaving the Philippines.

items.title: President Claudia Sheinbaum presses charges after groping incident in Mexico street
items.standfirst: Mexico's President Claudia Sheinbaum said Wednesday she's pressing charges against a man who groped her on the street a day earlier. The big picture: Video of Tuesday's incident on a Mexico City street went viral and Sheinbaum said on X that she would "review the legislation so that this crime is…

items.title: Mexico’s President Sheinbaum presses charges after groping attack on street
items.standfirst: Sheinbaum calls for review of sexual harassment laws, as attack shines light on Mexico's poor record on women's safety.
items.content: Sheinbaum calls for review of sexual harassment laws, as attack shines light on Mexico's poor record on women's safety.

items.title: Mexican president to press charges after video shows her being groped
items.standfirst: Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum announced that she will press charges against a man who appears to grope her while she was walking between government buildings in Mexico City, where a crowd had gathered. Police arrested the suspect, who can be seen trying to kiss the president before reaching for her chest. The country has faced elevated rates of gender-based violence, as well as violence against local politicians.
items.content: Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum announced that she will press charges against a man who appears to grope her while she was walking between government buildings in Mexico City, where a crowd had gathered. Police arrested the suspect, who can be seen trying to kiss the president before reaching for her chest. The country has faced elevated rates of gender-based violence, as well as violence against local politicians.

items.title: Mexico’s President Claudia Sheinbaum presses charges after being groped in street
items.standfirst: In Mexico, a man who groped President Sheinbaum and tried to kiss her is in police custody. The incident is reigniting a national and global conversation about harassment. NBC News’ Ellison Barber has the story.
items.content: In Mexico, a man who groped President Sheinbaum and tried to kiss her is in police custody. The incident is reigniting a national and global conversation about harassment. NBC News’ Ellison Barber has the story.

items.title: Mexico president to seek charges after being groped on street
items.standfirst: Claudia Sheinbaum says she is pressing charges because "a line must be drawn" against the harassment of Mexican women.
items.content: Claudia Sheinbaum says she is pressing charges because "a line must be drawn" against the harassment of Mexican women.

items.title: Man arrested after groping Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum on street
items.standfirst: Mexico President Claudia Sheinbaum says the harassment she suffered from a drunk man near the government seat is an assault on all women.
items.content: Mexico President Claudia Sheinbaum says the harassment she suffered from a drunk man near the government seat is an assault on all women.

items.title: Man gropes Mexican president as she speaks to citizens on the streets
items.standfirst: Man tries to kiss and embrace Claudia Sheinbaum, highlighting security risk and harassment women face in MexicoThe Mexican president, Claudia Sheinbaum, has been groped by a man as she mingled with citizens on the streets of Mexico City, raising questions about the lack of presidential security and the level of sexual harassment the country’s women face.A video of the incident on Tuesday shows a visibly drunk man trying to kiss the president on the neck and embrace her from behind, as she removes his hands and turns to face him, before a government official steps in and places himself between them. Continue reading...
items.content: Man tries to kiss and embrace Claudia Sheinbaum, highlighting security risk and harassment women face in MexicoThe Mexican president, Claudia Sheinbaum, has been groped by a man as she mingled with citizens on the streets of Mexico City, raising questions about the lack of presidential security and the level of sexual harassment the country’s women face.A video of the incident on Tuesday shows a visibly drunk man trying to kiss the president on the neck and embrace her from behind, as she removes his hands and turns to face him, before a government official steps in and places himself between them. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum is pressing charges after being groped.
The incident occurred on a street in Mexico City.
Video of the incident went viral on social media.
Sheinbaum will review legislation regarding sexual harassment.
The suspect was arrested and tried to kiss the president.

clusters.title: What to know about the deadly UPS plane crash in Louisville, Kentucky
clusters.neutral_headline: 12 Dead in UPS Plane Crash in Louisville, Kentucky

items.title: What to know about the deadly UPS plane crash in Louisville, Kentucky
items.standfirst: The plane crashed and burst into flames on Tuesday in Louisville, killing at least 12 people and injuring nearly 20 others. The disaster also shut down the largest UPS package distribution hub.
items.content: The plane crashed and burst into flames on Tuesday in Louisville, killing at least 12 people and injuring nearly 20 others. The disaster also shut down the largest UPS package distribution hub.(Image credit: Jon Cherry)

items.title: How the UPS cargo plane crashed in Louisville, what we know about victims
items.standfirst: Officials confirmed that at least 12 people died. Kentucky’s governor warned that the death toll is expected to rise.
items.content: Officials confirmed that at least 12 people died. Kentucky’s governor warned that the death toll is expected to rise.

items.content: Airport CCTV footage shows the UPS cargo plane's left engine fell off during takeoff, according to investigators.

items.title: At least 12 dead after engine fell off UPS plane that crashed and exploded in Kentucky
items.standfirst: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — A UPS cargo plane’s left wing caught fire and an engine fell off just before it crashed and exploded after takeoff in Kentucky, a federal official said Wednesday, offering the first investigative details about a disaster that killed at least 12 people, including a child. Finding…

Finding…

items.content: Surviellance footage shows one of the plane's engines falling off during takeoff before the fatal crash, officials say.

items.standfirst: At least 12 people were killed and several others injured after a UPS plane crashed shortly after taking off from the Louisville International Airport on Tuesday.
items.content: At least 12 people were killed and several others injured after a UPS plane crashed shortly after taking off from the Louisville International Airport on Tuesday.

items.title: UPS plane crashes near Louisville airport, killing 12; black boxes found

items.content: The number of fatalities may increase after a UPS plane crashed Tuesday near the Louisville International Airport in Kentucky, Gov. Andy Beshear said.

items.content: Still images and aerial video footage appear to show the plane's left engine sitting just off the runway in Louisville, Kentucky.

items.title: UPS plane's engine fell off during crash in Louisville, NTSB official says
items.standfirst: There was a fire in the UPS plane's left wing and the engine "detached" during takeoff from Louisville International Airport in Kentucky, the NTSB official said.
items.content: There was a fire in the UPS plane's left wing and the engine "detached" during takeoff from Louisville International Airport in Kentucky, the NTSB official said.

items.title: Investigators recover black boxes in deadly UPS plane crash
items.standfirst: The National Transportation Safety Board is now leading the investigation into the deadly crash of a UPS cargo plane in Louisville, Kentucky. CBS News correspondent Nicole Valdes has the latest. Then, Capt. Laura Einsetler joins with analysis.
items.content: The National Transportation Safety Board is now leading the investigation into the deadly crash of a UPS cargo plane in Louisville, Kentucky. CBS News correspondent Nicole Valdes has the latest. Then, Capt. Laura Einsetler joins with analysis.

items.content: Three people have died and officials expect more fatalities after a UPS plane crashed during takeoff.

ai_summary: A UPS cargo plane crashed and exploded in Louisville, Kentucky.
At least 12 people died in the crash.
The plane's engine fell off during takeoff.
The airport reopened one runway after the crash.
The black boxes from the plane have been recovered.

items.title: Supreme Court signals doubts over Trump’s sweeping tariff powers
items.standfirst: Several Supreme Court justices from both ideological wings voiced scepticism Wednesday over President Donald Trump’s claim that emergency powers allow him to impose vast global tariffs, raising the prospect of limits on one of his most aggressive uses of executive authority.
items.content: Several Supreme Court justices from both ideological wings voiced scepticism Wednesday over President Donald Trump’s claim that emergency powers allow him to impose vast global tariffs, raising the prospect of limits on one of his most aggressive uses of executive authority.

clusters.title: France suspends Shein site over sex doll controversy
clusters.neutral_headline: France Moves to Suspend Shein Over Sex Doll, Weapon Complaints

items.title: France suspends Shein site over sex doll controversy
items.standfirst: The French government said it’s moving to temporarily suspend Shein’s web platform in the country after authorities found numerous unsavory and potentially illegal items for sale, including a childlike sex doll and weapons. Shein said it removed the sex doll and has paused its third-party…
items.content: The French government said it’s moving to temporarily suspend Shein’s web platform in the country after authorities found numerous unsavory and potentially illegal items for sale, including a childlike sex doll and weapons. Shein said it removed the sex doll and has paused its third-party…

items.title: Queues and protests: BBC at the Shein store opening in Paris
items.standfirst: The online shopping giant opened its first physical shop in the world - in a Parisian department store.
items.content: The online shopping giant opened its first physical shop in the world - in a Parisian department store.

items.title: Shein's 'extreme obsolescence and plagiarism' provides a 'quick fix' for consumers, expert says
items.standfirst: France started proceedings to suspend online fast-fashion retailer Shein after childlike sex dolls and weapons were found being sold on its site, marring the opening of the company's first shop in a Paris department store. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Nick Rees-Roberts, Professor of Media and Culture at the Sorbonne, says that Shein's model is one of 'extreme obsolescence and plagiarism' pointing to a 'global consumer capitalism that is dysfunctional'.
items.content: France started proceedings to suspend online fast-fashion retailer Shein after childlike sex dolls and weapons were found being sold on its site, marring the opening of the company's first shop in a Paris department store. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Nick Rees-Roberts, Professor of Media and Culture at the Sorbonne, says that Shein's model is one of 'extreme obsolescence and plagiarism' pointing to a 'global consumer capitalism that is dysfunctional'.

items.title: Shein: Opens first permanent store in Paris as scandal and criticism mount
items.standfirst: Despite administrative sanctions and an ongoing judicial investigation into the sale of child-like sex dolls, the Asian e-commerce giant opened its first permanent physical store in the world at the BHV on Wednesday.
items.content: Despite administrative sanctions and an ongoing judicial investigation into the sale of child-like sex dolls, the Asian e-commerce giant opened its first permanent physical store in the world at the BHV on Wednesday.

items.title: France moves to suspend Shein over sex dolls as debut store opens in Paris

Continue reading...
items.content: The fast-fashion retailer has faced a backlash after the childlike dolls were discovered for sale on its websiteThe French government has said it will suspend the fast-fashion shopping website Shein amid controversy over its sale of childlike sex dolls.The announcement came as Shein opened its first brick-and-mortar store in the world in Paris amid a heavy police presence. Continue reading...

items.title: France Seeks Shein Suspension on Sex Doll, Weapon Complaints
items.standfirst: The French government said it would temporarily suspend the Chinese e-commerce giant Shein, just hours after it opened its first store in Paris, following complaints over sales of childlike sex dolls and weapons on its platform.
items.content: The French government said it would temporarily suspend the Chinese e-commerce giant Shein, just hours after it opened its first store in Paris, following complaints over sales of childlike sex dolls and weapons on its platform.

ai_summary: France is moving to suspend Shein's website.
The suspension follows the discovery of inappropriate items.
The items included a childlike sex doll and weapons.
Shein opened its first physical store in Paris.
The store opening was met with protests and police presence.

Democrats also won governor races in Virginia and New Jersey.
Mamdani will be the youngest mayor since 1892.

clusters.title: Japan deploys the military to counter a surge in bear attacks
clusters.neutral_headline: Japan Deploys Military to Counter Bear Attacks

items.title: Japan deploys the military to counter a surge in bear attacks

items.title: Belgium to hold security meeting after drone sightings at airports and military bases
items.standfirst: Source says Russia ‘very probably’ responsible amid surge in incursions into European airspace since mid-SeptemberBelgium’s national security council will hold an emergency meeting on Thursday after drone sightings at airports caused chaos for travellers and raised security concerns.Arrivals and departures were halted for several hours on Tuesday evening at Belgium’s busiest airport, Brussels, leading to the cancellation of dozens of flights. The skies were also closed over Liège airport, an important hub for freight transport, leading to further cancellations, delays and diversions. Continue reading...
items.content: Source says Russia ‘very probably’ responsible amid surge in incursions into European airspace since mid-SeptemberBelgium’s national security council will hold an emergency meeting on Thursday after drone sightings at airports caused chaos for travellers and raised security concerns.Arrivals and departures were halted for several hours on Tuesday evening at Belgium’s busiest airport, Brussels, leading to the cancellation of dozens of flights. The skies were also closed over Liège airport, an important hub for freight transport, leading to further cancellations, delays and diversions. Continue reading...

items.title: Belgium probes drone sightings after flights halted overnight
items.standfirst: Belgian authorities on Wednesday investigated drone sightings that halted air traffic overnight at several airports, as flights resumed after hundreds of passengers were left stranded. The main airport in Brussels and another in Liege had to suspend arrivals and departures late Tuesday for several hours after suspected drones were spotted nearby. FRANCE 24's Monte Francis reports.
items.content: Belgian authorities on Wednesday investigated drone sightings that halted air traffic overnight at several airports, as flights resumed after hundreds of passengers were left stranded. The main airport in Brussels and another in Liege had to suspend arrivals and departures late Tuesday for several hours after suspected drones were spotted nearby. FRANCE 24's Monte Francis reports.
